image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

props.synopsis: A trailblazer from the remote Northern Territory, Dr Gondarra was known as a straight-talking spiritual and cultural leader who never lost sight of his quest for equality.

title.children: Trailblazing church minister, NT cultural leader and political fighter Dr Gondarra dies aged 79

image.altText: An Indigenous woman and man smile while looking directly at the camera.

props.synopsis: For thousands of people in the NT, overcrowded housing is a day-to-day reality. Now, a major investment into hundreds of new homes is looking to change that.

title.children: 'It's suffocating': The new plan trying to end the cramped reality of overcrowded housing

image.altText: A young mother hugging her young son

props.synopsis: The parents of a four-year-old boy are furious he was removed from his long-time early learning centre after being diagnosed with epilepsy. Advocates say it's not an isolated incident.

title.children: 'Textbook discrimination': Parents of boy removed from kinder after epilepsy diagnosis slam national provider

image.altText: An overhead shot of a large crowd of pilgrims wearing white. There is a mosque building to the left.

props.synopsis: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade confirms an Australian is among the hundreds to die completing the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.

title.children: Australian among hundreds dead in Saudi Arabia on Hajj pilgrimage

image.altText: Natalie Frahm, the woman killed by an alleged shooter in South Mackay.

props.synopsis: A quiet cul-de-sac in Mackay was the scene of a shooting this week that claimed the life of Natalie Frahm — and police still don't know why.

title.children: Shock and grief as Mackay mourns victim of shooting in quiet cul-de-sac

image.altText: An older man with a beard wearing a suit next to another man in a grey jumper.

props.synopsis: Kiefer Sutherland describes his father — who appeared in nearly 200 films and series over five decades — as "one of the most important actors in the history of film".

title.children: Donald Sutherland, the actor whose career spanned from the M*A*S*H film to Hunger Games, dies at 88

image.altText: A woman in a blue top blowing her nose using a tissue

props.synopsis: It's not an extraordinary year in terms of the flu or RSV "in isolation", but this year's winter season is unusual because there are many things circulating together.

title.children: Between the flu, COVID and RSV, we have 'so many things circulating simultaneously'. Here's what the data says

image.altText: A photo of Keith Kerinauia being escorted by a prison security guard at the BWS Airport Tavern bottleshop.

props.synopsis: A jury has found Keith Kerinauia guilty of the murder of Darwin bottle shop worker Declan Laverty, following an eight-day trial in the NT Supreme Court.

title.children: Keith Kerinauia found guilty of murdering Darwin bottle shop worker Declan Laverty

image.altText: an offshore jack-up drill rig.

props.synopsis: NT government-owned utility the Power and Water Corporation has revealed the territory's shortfall in gas supply cost taxpayers $43.4 million in 2023-24, and is estimated to cost another $24.3 million next financial year.

title.children: Emergency gas deals to cost NT taxpayers almost $70m over two years, utility reveals

image.altText: Albanese is seen through the window of a manufacturing facility, production line equipment in the foreground.

props.synopsis: The government knows it can't compete with China to make cheaper solar panels. But it's placing a billion-dollar bet that it can outcompete the manufacturing giant on technology to transform Australia's tiny solar industry.

title.children: Australia is placing a billion-dollar bet on making solar panels. It's exciting some, and alarming others

image.altText: Loy Yang power station in the La Trobe Valley, east of Melbourne.

props.synopsis: The Coalition wants to build nuclear reactors at seven locations across the country, with several sites on or near known fault lines. And while nowhere is immune to earthquake risk, the bigger problem could be an increase to engineering costs.

title.children: Some of the Coalition's proposed nuclear locations are near fault lines — is that a problem?

image.altText: A landscape view of waterfront mansions on a sunny blue-sky day. An empty ocean pool is in the foreground

props.synopsis: Since the mid-19th century, the church has owned a large swathe of land in southern Manly, which it now leases out on decades-long, multi-million-dollar agreements.

title.children: The beachside suburb where residents have an unusual landlord: the Catholic Church

image.altText: The exterior of the Nvidia HQ in Santa Clara.

props.synopsis: After briefly becoming the world's most valuable company this week, Nvidia has shifted to second place following a drop on Wall Street. It comes as the Bank of England kept interest rates on hold overnight. Follow live.

title.children: Nvidia loses title as world's most valuable company to Microsoft, UK central bank keeps rates on hold

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Could the UK get a rate cut in August? Its central bank suggests it's possible
ICYMI: Guzman y Gomez's first day on the ASX
Microsoft regains its crown as world's most valuable company

image.altText: A man with glasses speaking at a press conference

props.synopsis: In the timing of his announcement, Peter Dutton is putting his nuclear power policy through an early stress test, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Peter Dutton's nuclear power policy is about to go through an early stress test

image.altText: Container of nuclear waste being loaded onto truck by crane

props.synopsis: Australia currently produces a relatively small amount of radioactive waste due to its limited nuclear industry, so what would happen to the waste generated by seven nuclear reactors if they were built under a Coalition government?

title.children: Radioactive waste comes under spotlight as Coalition moves to embrace nuclear future

image.altText: Woman sits at the front of a crowded room in a bookstore

props.synopsis: Author Candice Fox has written numerous bestselling novels. And while many people think they have a book in them, it's not as easy as she makes it look. Here she shares her tips on how to write a crime novel.

title.children: Ever wanted to write a crime novel? Bestselling author Candice Fox has some advice on how to write and how to get published

image.altText: Two adults and three kids smile in a selfie

props.synopsis: Marc didn't know he had 19 super accounts and multiple life insurance policies. He's urging others to check their finances to avoid hefty fees eating away at the balance.

title.children: More than 4 million Australians urged to track down $16 billion in lost, unclaimed super

image.altText: An electron microscope image of Group A Streptococcus bacteria interacting with a human neutrophil

props.synopsis: You might have seen headlines about an outbreak of STSS in Japan. Here's a breakdown of what it is and whether you should be worried.

title.children: What is the 'flesh-eating bacteria' outbreak in Japan? Here's what to know

image.altText: A fire engine arrives to put out a mound of rubbish that caught fire.

props.synopsis: As state ministers get set to meet with the Minister for Environment, 7.30 can reveal the high number of fires caused by lithium-ion batteries.

title.children: 'Matter of urgency': As lithium-ion batteries explode, waste chiefs say change is necessary

image.altText: Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama in yellow and red robe.

props.synopsis: The Chinese foreign ministry says the Dalai Lama — the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism — must "thoroughly correct" his political views, as US poilticians push a bill aimed at pressing China to secure a negotiated and peaceful agreement on Tibet.

title.children: China says Dalai Lama must 'thoroughly correct' his political views

image.altText: A Serbian fan with his face painted, a shirtless England fan cheering and Italy goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma.

props.synopsis: England tries to head off criticism from fans, Serbia threatens to boycott, and Spain advances past Italy. Here are five quick hits from overnight at the Euros.

title.children: Five quick hits: Serbia threatens to quit Euros over racist chants and England still defending even after 1-1 draw

image.altText: A blue, pumpkin shaped mushroom growing on a log

props.synopsis: Australia has up to 250,000 species of fungus but only a fraction of them have been named and described. A group of citizen scientists is working to change that.

title.children: Australia's fungi fanatics are filling in the gaps left by scientists

image.altText: Two men are standing next to each other and each holding one hand up. The flags of Russia and Vietnam are behind them.

props.synopsis: The United States has strongly criticised Vietnam's decision to host Vladimir Putin. The Russian President is looking to Asian countries for support as he has been largely isolated from the West.

title.children: Russia and Vietnam sign new agreements, day after Putin's North Korea visit

image.altText: Rishi Sunak stands behind a wooden lectern in the street speaking in the rain

props.synopsis: The rapidly escalating gambling scandal is the latest misfortune to unfold for Mr Sunak, who is forecast to lose power on July 4 after a campaign characterised by gaffes that followed his surprise announcement of an early vote.

title.children: Campaign chief for UK PM Rishi Sunak's party steps aside in insider gambling scandal

image.altText: A designed image of Rihanna and Beyonce smiling against a sparkly yellow and purple background

props.synopsis: It's hard to name an A-Lister who has yet to launch their own cosmetics line. As celebrities become less the face of brands and start becoming founders, some of the biggest names show where this billion-dollar industry is heading.

title.children: Beyoncé can sell out stadiums – here's why she's now selling shampoo

image.altText: ndia header

props.synopsis: A Labor MP suggests NDIA officials could have been "inappropriately cultivated" by a US software firm that holds a lucrative contract.

title.children: US software firm took NDIA officials to fine-dining restaurants and golf days. The gifts weren't declared

image.altText: A chicken stares into the camera with more chickens and their movable shed in the background.

props.synopsis: A strain of high pathogenicity avian influenza was detected on a poultry farm in the Hawkesbury this week, as other subtypes of bird flu have made its way across the country.

title.children: What you need to know about the NSW bird flu outbreak

image.altText: Close up of a beluga whale grey in colour

props.synopsis: Two beluga whales faced a gruelling journey across Ukraine's war-ravaged region of Kharkiv to reach their new home in Spain.

title.children: Beluga whales saved from bombing in Ukraine in 'the most complex marine mammal rescue ever'

image.altText: In the rain, a Mercedes car leads the Red Bull, with spray rising from wheels

props.synopsis: The European swing of the Formula 1 season truly begins this weekend, as the teams descend on Barcelona.

title.children: F1 is competitive again and teams are now ready to bring upgrades to their cars

image.altText: A woman with an orange paint over airplane

props.synopsis: Climate activists have gained access to a UK airport where they claimed Taylor Swift's luxury plane was stationed, however police later confirmed her aircraft was never there.

title.children: Climate activists arrested after spraying paint onto private jets at airport where they thought Taylor Swift's plane was stationed

image.altText: A CCTV grainy photo of a white utility on a road.

props.synopsis: A 27-year-old pedestrian dies after an alleged road rage incident in Western Sydney as police search for the driver of a ute they say hit the man before fleeing the scene.

title.children: Police search for ute driver over alleged fatal road rage attack in Western Sydney

image.altText: A real estate agency on left and a man with crossed arms on right.

props.synopsis: The ABC has spoken to 10 people about their experiences with property agent Ballarat Real Estate, alleging unethical and improper conduct, and potential breaches of the law.

title.children: Former clients engage Consumer Affairs after 'heartbreaking' conduct of Ballarat Real Estate
